21.heading: Radio Operators.
21.title: "The Flight of the Silver Saucers"
21.author: [No author]
21.series: Captain Wings) 10 p. in Wings Comics, no. 112
notes: Title from cover.
Though the art is substantially the same, this story is a thorough re-write of the Captain Wings story in Wings Comics, no. 53 (Jan. 1945), where it is signed "L. Elias."

Summary: "Madam X" is a grounded bomber upon which "whiz-bombs" have been inappropriately mounted. It has been damaged and its crew is injured, and the plane is scheduled to be dismantled. A Japanese Zero crash-lands near the base, and a woman survives, managing to make the men think they've captured secret plans. After the squadron has left to take advantage of the plans, the woman steals a gun and kills the radio operator. The crew of Madam X figures out what has happened, and leaves sick bay in a suicide mission to spring the ambush the Japanese have set up. On page 7, a Japanese radioman says, "Silver disks
our greatest arsenal gone! Shoot down that plane at any cost!" The whiz-bomb shown in p. 1 does seem to be disc-shaped, though from the title and cover art we would expect flying saucer UFOs.

22.heading: Radio Operators.
22.title: "Voices"

notes: Summary: A radio operator builds a set that can hear the future. He hears his own death announced, and tries to cheat fate by suicide. The broadcast was a practical joke by his friends.

55.heading: Radio Personalities.
55.title: "Hasta la Vista Amigo" p. 57-66 in Kraken, by Antonio Segura and Jordi Bernet
55.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Raul Castillo, an old college friend of Lieutenant Dante, has become a radio personality and is broadcasting adventure documentaries about the sewers and the heroic police who patrol them. Actually he is a drug addict now, and is working for cocaine smugglers, scouting out routes for them. When Dante figures this out he goes to visit Raul, and arrives to find he has committed suicide.

130.heading: Radio Stations.
130.title: "I Sent the Money Back"
130.author: by Aaron McGruder.
notes: Summary: Granddad accidently won a radio contest, but then thought of all the "filthy music" the station plays.

131.heading: Radio Stations.
131.title: "Radio-Réveil"
131.author: Dupa
notes: Summary: Cubitus treats his new radio alarm so badly that the station has to go off the air.

132.heading: Radio Stations.
132.title: "Secret Radio Messages"
132.author: [No author]
132.series: Ned of the Navy) 6 p. in Silver Streak Comics, no. 21
notes: SUMMARY: A swinging San Francisco radio station's dedication messages have been tipping off the Japanese navy. I. Ned of the Navy. k. Radio stations. k. Messages. k. Swinging. k. San Francisco (Calif.) k. Dedications. k. Tipoffs. k. Japanese Navy. Call no.: Film 15791, r.188

133.heading: Radio Stations.
133.title: "Sensible"
133.author: [No author]
133.series: Condorito) p. 66 in Condorito de Oro, no. 75
notes: The radio station's new equipment is so sensitive that the microphone cries if you speak harshly.

134.heading: Radio Stations.
134.title: "What Happened ta Toscanini?"
134.author: by Jayzey Lynch
134.appears_in: 2 p. in Yellow Dog Comics, no. 15 (v. 2, no. 3) (1969).
notes: Pat uses a sonic boom and a bomb threat to get the radio station to play rhythm n' blues.

135.heading: Radio Talk Shows.
135.title: "Anti-Testosterone Legislation"
135.author: Susan Dewar.
notes: Key words: Title IX, men's athletics, WNBA, olympics, radio talk shows.

136.heading: Radio Talk Shows.
136.title: "Changed his Tune"
136.author: Susan Dewar.
notes: Summary: Women have been denied their due for too long, and his bosses are women.
Key words: Women's athletics, Title IX, radio talk shows.

137.heading: Radio Talk Shows.
137.title: "25th Anniversary of Title IX"
137.author: Susan Dewar.
notes: Summary: Let's have Title X, use political correctness to get rid of provoking commentators.
Key words: Radio talk shows, college athletics.

138.heading: Radio Telescopes.
138.title: "Talking it Over with Father John" text p. 16-17 in Treasure Chest of Fun and Fact, v. 16, no. 13
138.author: [No author]
notes: Begins: "There is some mighty big listening going on these days! The biggest listening job in history is being done by the 'Big Ear," the name given to the giant saucer-shaped antenna of the radio telescope at Green Bank, West Virginia. The listening job is named Project Ozma."

140.heading: Radio Transcripts.

contents.title: Donald, diese hehre Ente, lieben wir mit Vehemente (1977)
Frau Doktor Fuchs, Micky Maus und ich (1976)
Dem Ingeniör ist nichts zu schwör (1976).

notes: ca. 100 leaves ; 30 cm.
Radio scripts for Deutschlandfunk programs on Disney comics in Germany, including material about comics writer Erika Fuchs.

141.heading: Radio Transmitters.
141.title: "The Sphinx Speaks"
141.author: by Joe Simon and Jack Kirby
141.appears_in: 12 p. in Detective Comics, no. 66 (Aug. 1942) ; reprinted in Boy Commandos, no. 1 (Oct. 1973)
notes: SUMMARY: A reporter in the year 3045 interviews an Egyptian mummy, who tells a story from the past (1942) when German soldiers installed a radio transmitter in the Sphinx. The mummy got his Brooklyn accent from Brooklyn of the Boy Commandos. I. Simon, Joe. II. Kirby, Jack. III. The Boy Commandos. k. Reporters. k. Interviews. k. Egyptian Mummies. k. Mummies. k. German Soldiers. k. Radio Transmitters. k. Brooklyn Accents. Call no.: PN6728.1.N3D4m no.66

145.heading: Radio Wires.
145.title: "Revenge!" 4 p. in Warfront, no. 17
145.author: [No author]
notes: Korean War story: Johnny Rektor's best friend was killed by the enemy while a prisoner of war, and in a rage Johnny rips out the radio wires in his jet plane and becomes a 'one-man atrocity avenger', until he runs out of ammunition and is shot down by his own artillery.

146.title: Radio Patrol
notes: Newspaper comic strip by Eddie Sullivan and Charlie Schmidt
